Bei der Prostata-Biopsie, die derzeit (noch) meist transrektal durchgeführt wird, geht der Biopsie-Weg durch ein hoch mit intestinalem Mikrobiom besiedeltes Gebiet.

In der Literatur sind Infektionsraten von 0,4 bis 7 % nach TRPB beschrieben.
Es wurden auch schwere Infektionen, die eine Klinikeinweisung erforderten, Sepsis (1-3 %) und Todesfälle beobachtet (0,1-1,3 %) [Stangl-Kremser 2023, Fontana 2018].

Zu den Infektionserregern gehören in erster Linie Escherichia coli gefolgt von Enterokokken, ferner Enterobacterales (Enterobacter spp., Klebsiella spp. Proteus spp.), selten Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Als Risikofaktoren werden u.a. vorausgegangene Antibiotikatherapie, häufige Harnwegsinfektionen und eine intestinale Besiedelung mit multiresistenten gramnegativen Bakterien (MRGN) beschrieben [Liss 2014].

Biopsies are traditionally performed along with antibi- otic prophylaxis to reduce the risk of infectious complica- tions. Despite low certainty data for infection risk, the transperineal approach is strongly recommended for prostate biopsy due to its significant lower risk of infectious complications and better antibiotic stewardship. For transrectal biopsies, targeted prophylaxis (based on rectal swab/stool culture) or augmented prophylaxis (two or more antibiotic classes) is essential, given the increase in fluoroquinolone resistance which also strongly advises against their use (e.g., due to legal implications in Europe), necessitating alternatives like cephalosporins or aminoglycosides where fluoroquinolones are suspended. (Confidence: 100.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Transrectal Prostate Biopsy: High Infection Risk, Safer Alternatives.
nuggets: TRUS-PB is the gold standard for prostate cancer diagnosis but is associated with high morbidity from complications like infection, hospitalization, and sepsis, which are significantly higher than with the transperineal method; studies show 0/245 transperineal patients hospitalized and only 5/6609 sepsis hospitalizations in a literature review. Additional precautions to reduce infection include disposable needles, povidone-iodine needle cleaning, rectal swab culture, and rectal mucosa cleaning with antiseptic solutions (chlorhexidine/povidone-iodine) or saline, which is cheap, easy, and provides protection against infections, serving as an alternative for those with antiseptic allergies. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Infection rates following transrectal prostate biopsy (TRPB) range from 0.4% to 7%, with sepsis rates varying from 0.3% to 9.4%, and severe complications including infections requiring hospitalization and deaths (0.1-1.3%) having been observed. While two RCTs showed no higher rates of infections, fever, or sepsis when prophylactic antibiotic prophylaxis (PAP) was omitted, less severe urinary tract infections were three times more frequent, with an absolute difference of 0.73% (95% CI: 1.08-2.81). (Confidence: 100.0%)

"TRexit" refers to a deviation from transrectal practices in prostate biopsy, with the objectives of mitigating infection risks and the emergence of resistant microbial strains, while preserving diagnostic precision. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: TRANSLATE: LATP Safety, Infection Reduction, Antibiotic Stewardship
nuggets: The TRANSLATE trial reported fewer infections (including those requiring hospital admission) for LATP versus TRUS, although this difference was not statistically significant given it was a secondary outcome for which the trial was not powered. To increase diversity, TRANSLATE excluded London and many other major UK cities where hospitals had already fully transitioned to LATP. (Confidence: 80.0%)

The UK TRANSLATE study, which demonstrated most LATP biopsies can be safely performed without antibiotics (benefiting antibiotic stewardship), excluded high-risk participants and did not routinely incorporate targeted, enhanced, or rectal culture-guided antibiotic prophylaxis (a practice used in some other countries). Despite these factors, its overall reported infection rates were higher than other studies due to comprehensive data collection. (Confidence: 80.0%)

The TRANSLATE study found that local anaesthetic transperineal (LATP) biopsies led to fewer post-biopsy infection hospitalisations compared to transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) biopsies, and that most LATP biopsies can be safely performed without antibiotics, given 89% of LATP cases did not receive them (with the 11% that did largely being protocol deviations), which supports antibiotic stewardship, with overall infection rates being low and comparable to PROBE-PC and PREVENT.18. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: TP Biopsy: Safe Antibiotic Omission for Stewardship
nuggets: Transperineal biopsy (TP-Tbx) can safely omit prophylactic antibiotics without increasing infection risk, effectively supporting antibiotic stewardship and reducing reliance on broad-spectrum antibiotics. This contrasts with transrectal biopsy (TR-Tbx) and its infection concerns, making TP-Tbx the favored approach for infection-related outcomes, despite some lacking statistical significance. (Confidence: 80.0%)

The choice of biopsy approach holds broad relevance as it impacts clinical outcomes, healthcare resources, and patient quality of life; however, the multicenter nature of studies and varying clinician experience and equipment across sites may influence the reproducibility of biopsy techniques. (Confidence: 80.0%)

TP biopsy, appearing safe without antibiotics in patients without risk factors, significantly reduces antibiotic usage by lowering infectious complications and post-procedural admission risks compared to TR biopsy. This approach supports enhanced antimicrobial stewardship by addressing the major implications of antibiotic overuse and associated antimicrobial resistance for individual patients and the general population. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Rectal Swab TPAs Reduce fUTI Post-Prostate Biopsy
nuggets: TPAs based on rectal swab culture reduced the risk of fUTI by 46% compared with empiric prophylactic antibiotics; however, the influence of quinolone-resistant bacteria on this effectiveness remains unclear as its varying prevalence was not considered, and these findings cannot be directly extrapolated to current or future clinical practice due to anticipated changes in prophylactic antibiotic usage. (Confidence: 80.0%)

Performing rectal swab-based TPAs is recommended in patients undergoing TRUS-PB for PCa diagnosis, as it significantly and clinically relevantly reduces the incidence of fUTI compared with empiric prophylactic antibiotics. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: LATP vs. TRUS Biopsy: TRANSLATE Trial Findings
nuggets: For prostate cancer diagnosis, local anaesthetic transperineal (LATP) biopsy is gaining popularity over traditional transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) biopsy, primarily due to concerns about infectious complications with TRUS and LATP's perceived superior targeting of MRI-visible lesions. However, uncertainties persist regarding LATP's infection rates, prostate sampling, tolerability, side-effects, and cost-effectiveness, with the TRANSLATE trial providing evidence to inform the trade-offs in choosing between these methods. (Confidence: 80.0%)

The TRANSLATE trial found LATP detected GGG 2 or higher prostate cancer in 60.1% (329/547) of participants compared to 54.4% (294/540) for TRUS biopsy (OR 1.32, p=0.031), demonstrating greater detection; however, LATP caused higher immediate post-procedure pain/embarrassment and took longer, while TRUS biopsy resulted in more procedure-related symptoms beyond 7 days. Systematic biopsies are crucial for overall detection of GGG 2 or higher prostate cancer, and regional biopsies add value beyond target-only approaches. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: LATP Biopsy: Fewer Antibiotics, Less Infection
nuggets: LATP biopsy was performed with chlorhexidine-based skin preparation, without antibiotics. (Confidence: 80.0%)

Most participants who received LATP underwent biopsy without antibiotics according to protocol (503 [89%] of 567), with the remaining 11% largely due to protocol deviations, while all participants in the TRUS group received antibiotics; LATP also resulted in fewer post-biopsy infection hospitalizations compared to TRUS. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Transperineal Prostate Biopsy: Less Infection, Fewer Antibiotics.
nuggets: Although transrectal (ultrasound-guided) prostate biopsy (TRPB) has been the gold standard approach for decades, the current European Association of Urology (EAU) guidelines now recommend transperineal prostate biopsy (TPPB) due to its comparably lower rates of infectious complications, including infection, hospitalization, and sepsis. Nevertheless, TRPB continues to be widely performed worldwide for various practical reasons, and antibiotic prophylaxis with povidone-iodine rectal preparation are recommended if TRPB is planned. (Confidence: 100.0%)

From pragmatic and forward-looking perspectives, the transperineal biopsy (TPB) approach should be favored, as current high-confidence studies suggest it does not require prophylactic antibiotic prophylaxis (PAP) and is not inferior in infectious endpoints compared to PAP-accompanied transrectal biopsy (TRB), which always necessitates PAP. This choice is particularly relevant given the projected doubling of global prostate cancer incidence by 2040 and the questionable feasibility of routinely implementing rectal cultures for targeted PAP in TRB. (Confidence: 100.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Minimizing Urological Infection Risk: Biopsy Choices and Antibiotics
nuggets: Urological surgeons must maintain an aseptic environment through proper instrument cleaning and sterilization, and establish local guidelines based on pathogen prevalence, antibiotic susceptibility profiles, and virulence. (Confidence: 100.0%)

While both transrectal (TR) and transperineal (TP) prostate biopsies offer similar diagnostic power for cancer, the TP approach is associated with significantly fewer infectious complications, including a reported 77% lower risk of hospitalization, and safely allows antibiotic prophylaxis omission, consistent with antimicrobial stewardship and European Association of Urology recommendations. In contrast, TR biopsies, though less resource-intensive and potentially causing less patient discomfort, require antibiotic prophylaxis and carry a higher risk of severe infections. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Targeted Prophylaxis Reduces TRPB Infectious Complications
nuggets: Several reports, including a meta-analysis of 15 studies (12,320 patients), demonstrate that rectal culture-directed antimicrobial prophylaxis, based on pre-biopsy screening for resistant pathogens, is an effective and reasonable approach to reduce post-biopsy infectious complications in TRPB patients, lowering incidence from 3.4% with empirical prophylaxis to 0.8% with targeted prophylaxis. A separate multicenter, randomized controlled trial enrolled 403 TRPB patients with low risks of infectious complications, adhering to current criteria. (Confidence: 100.0%)

TRBx inherently risks infection, particularly sepsis, with numerous studies consistently demonstrating a higher incidence of infectious complications, including symptomatic UTIs and fever, compared to TPBx (e.g., He et al. [10]). For TRBx, antibiotics were administered together with rectal cultures, and targeted antibiotics were prescribed. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: FQ Resistance Drives Targeted Prophylaxis in Prostate Biopsy
nuggets: Fluoroquinolones (FQs) are suspended for prostate biopsy by the European Commission due to increased resistance, yet targeted therapy based on rectal swab microbiology significantly reduces infectious complications in cases of FQ resistance (9 RCTs, 3,096 patients). While cephalosporins or aminoglycosides can be used as alternatives with comparable infectious complications where FQs are suspended (2 RCTs), the applicability of targeted prophylaxis to non-FQ antibiotics is unclear, with no RCTs available for non-FQ targeted prophylaxis; consequently, specific agent recommendations are not made due to global variations in pathogens, susceptibility, and antibiotic availability. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Due to increasing rectal colonization by fluoroquinolone (FQ)-resistant and ESBL-producing *E. coli*, which causes acute prostatitis after transrectal prostate biopsy (TRPB), traditional FQ prophylaxis is ineffective and increasingly restricted, making pre-biopsy rectal cultures with selective media a logical and effective method to guide targeted antimicrobial prophylaxis (e.g., TAZ/PIPC) for preventing severe complications and reducing healthcare costs. (Confidence: 100.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: EAU Recommends Transperineal Prostate Biopsy, Citing Infection Reduction
nuggets: The European Association of Urology (EAU) guidelines on prostate cancer strongly recommend the transperineal approach for prostate biopsy due to its lower risk of infectious complications [28]. While emerging evidence and a meta-analysis suggest antibiotic prophylaxis may not be necessary for transperineal biopsies—finding no significant differences in UTI and sepsis rates—formal recommendations are pending further research, though high-risk patients for UTIs may still benefit. (Confidence: 80.0%)

Urology association guidelines, particularly from the European Association of Urology (EAU) and the American Urological Association (AUA), currently provide conflicting recommendations on the optimal prostate biopsy approach; the EAU strongly recommends the transperineal (TP) method due to its reduced incidence of infectious complications [12]. (Confidence: 80.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: TRPB Post-Biopsy Prostatitis Prevention Strategies
nuggets: For patients with low infectious risks, screening with highly accurate LVFX-insusceptible selective media (98.1% sensitivity, 94.7% specificity) before TRPB may provide additive value in preventing post-biopsy prostatitis. TAZ/PIPC can be recommended when FQ-resistant or ESBL-producing E. coli is detected, though further evaluation of selective media screening is needed for patients with underlying immune-compromising conditions. (Confidence: 100.0%)

clusters.cluster_heading: Rectal Culture Prophylaxis: Effectiveness, Resistance, and Practice Variations
nuggets: Due to rising antimicrobial resistance, including fluoroquinolone resistance as high as 45% [35,37], rectal culture-based antibiotic prophylaxis significantly reduces infectious complications compared to empirical antibiotics, which are the least effective measure. However, studies show variations in the choice, dosage, and duration of antibiotics, rectal cleansing agents, and rectal culture methodology. (Confidence: 80.0%)
